 - 41 - ANNEX B REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN PILOT POVERTY ALLEVIATION PROJECT SHELTER AND HOUSE REHABILITATION PROGRAM (SAVE THE CHILDREN-US) SUMMARY 1. The proposed two-and-a-half year project will alleviate poverty through assisting 2000 returned families in the self-help reconstruction of their homes in five districts most devastated by the recent civil war. This is 37% of the identified need. 420 tonnes of food (wheat flour, beans and oil) will be provided to over 100 work groups each of 15-20 persons, representing an estimated 210,000 days of labor. At least 2000 other families are expected to benefit through reduction of overcrowding, double and triple family occupancy of single homes being common. The project will also promote the adoption of environmentally sound roofing technology ie. use of fiber-cement tiles in place of asbestos roofing sheets. Local communities will be involved in beneficiary identification, monitoring of food distribution and construction, and in the identification of subsequent priorities in poverty alleviation. The project will be self-targeting, with controls to ensure the inclusion of the neediest beneficiaries and to prevent misallocation of inputs. The project will operate in the priority need districts areas of: Bokhtar, Vakhsh, Kolkhozabad, Kabodien and Shaartuz districts in the Khatlon region of Tajikistan. The project would be implemented by SCF-US Tajikistan and would have a budget of $3.5 million. OBJECTIVES 2. Much of the devastation during the 1992-3 civil war was concentrated in two areas of Western Khatlon Region. In some instances entire villages were razed. Although UNHCR and SCF-US have assisted many thousands to rebuild their homes, there remains a backlog of over 6,000 identified families whose houses are not rebuilt, the most needy districts being Bokhtar (2,000 houses), Vakhsh (1,700) Kabodien and Shaartuz (750 each) and Kolkhozabad (400). These numbers are increasing as more families return to their ruined homes. Most of these families cannot feed themselves or satisfy basic health and education needs, let alone finance reconstruction. Even if they had the resources, locally available roofing materials are lacking. Basic shelter (2-3 rooms) is a fundamental precondition for economic rehabilitation, which can be carried out through other means (development of household plots, income generation activities, employment creation, re-establishment of social service infrastructure). Therefore it is not surprising that the social assessment of the Bank identified housing needs as a critical priority of the poor. 3. Compounding the situation is massive unemployment and underemployment; factories and enterprises are non-functioning, the micro-economies of the kolkhozes and sovkhozes is in advanced decline, and workers have either been laid off or receive no salaries, or partial and irregular salaries. Skilled craftsmen, including carpenters, builders, mechanics, are largely idle or have left Tajikistan to find employment elsewhere in the CIS. Finally, there is a chronic and serious food deficit. On a different level, there is a pressing need to reestablish security, law and order, community cohesion, and
 - 42 - an atmosphere of trust and cooperation between local communities and local governments and institutions, so that people can begin to resume normal lives. The cramped, destitute living conditions of the populations can only serve to create or exacerbate local tensions. 4. The project would aim to alleviate poverty by satisfying a significant portion (37 percent) of the identified housing needs within two years, creating employment through seasonal local work groups, and fostering community cooperation and solidarity through such neighborhood associations. The project would also temporarily relieve the food deficit, pending an eventual rise in local food production, and support local entrepreneurs and craftsmen in the promotion of an environmentally-sound technology: the production and use of fiber-cement tiles. 5. Specific objectives would be that, by the end of two years (March 1997 to March 1999): (a) Two thousand needy homeless families would have reconstructed basic shelter (kitchen, living room/bedroom) with assistance from local Food For Work (FFW) brigades. (b) Local community FFW brigades would have carried out reconstruction activities for 2000 houses, and improved their families' food security through the estimated 420 MT of food (wheat flour, beans, oil) which would be distributed as compensation for approximately 210,000 days equivalent of labor (note: FFW calculations are based on reconstruction completed, not time spent). (c) The demonstrated practice of community participation in reconstruction, needs identification and monitoring would have produced measurable positive changes in community attitudes towards defining and meeting local development needs, both in the project area and in other parts of the country (indirect benefit). (d) The successful use of fiber-cement roofing tiles would have supported the expansion of an environmentally-friendly technology, the creation a cadre of skilled workers, both within the program area and in other parts of the country (indirect benefit). STRATEGY AND TARGETING 6. The strategy would aim to alleviate poverty through supporting community self-help efforts to create the physical and social infrastructure that will enable a community to address more long-term needs. The area selected contains a majority of returned refugees and IDPs who need to be reintegrated into local communities. Further direct targeting of beneficiaries would be undertaken during the project to ensure that benefits will be targeted to the neediest families. The project beneficiaries would be primarily, although not necessarily exclusively, the neediest families with many small children, widows, families caring for orphans and pensioners, and would include an equitable proportion of women-headed households. Currently, approximately 30 per cent of the brigade members are women, many brigades have a majority of women members, and some brigades are entirely composed of women. Similarly all efforts have been made to ensure mixed ethnicity within the brigades. Emphasis is placed on this being a community project, with equal participation from all elements of the community.
 - 43 - 7. The FFW element is designed to relieve food deficits, and to foster local cooperation in shelter reconstruction. The donated supply of basic construction materials, beyond the means of poor families to acquire, is supplemented by a significant local contribution in labor and in finishing. Work groups make use of local skills. 8. The above strategy has been shown to be a popular and effective way to meet several needs simultaneously: reinforced community organization and participation, shortage of construction materials, and shortage of food and employment opportunities, particularly for unemployed skilled artisans and unskilled labor. The seasonal work program meshes well with off-season work in canal clearing. The specific steps to implement the strategy, explained further below under the section on implementation, are: (a) Extensive village meetings are held to inform people of the project, undertake social mapping, identify eligible and needy beneficiaries and particularly ensure the inclusion of women, calculate FFW and material requirements; (b) Village work brigades are formed and a work plan prepared; (c) Materials and food are procured, and their delivery and utilization monitored both by the local representatives and the NGO. 9. Two new elements have been included in the strategy of this project in order to improve effectiveness and coverage. (a) As a sub-component of the project a subcontractor would supply tiels and train local carpenters and artisans in roof construction (which is slightly different from that required for asbestos sheeting), quality control and repairs. In order to demonstrate the technology and determine training needs, three demonstration houses would be roofed with tiles prior to project effectiveness. The use of roofing tiles in place of the previously-used asbestos sheets would remove a potential health hazard, and support additional employment that would disseminate this technology more widely. (b) Site visits and training will be arranged for a small number of selected community representatives and government officials from other parts of the country where there is an identified housing need (rural Penjikent, Aini, Mascho), with a view to building capacity in other local organizations for similar programs. The addition of a small training and extension component will enable the methodology to be adopted and adapted to the needs of other areas where SCF-US does not work, and where similar housing needs of the very poor exist for reasons other than destruction in civil war.
 - 44 - ACTIVITIES 10. Extensive village meetings would be held to inform people of the program modalities and its limitations. Direct selection of the neediest areas is done initially from an already-prepared list of beneficiaries, through community-based participatory social mapping, and consultation with other NGOs working in the area and key community resource people (particularly informal leaders, neighborhood (mahallah) community representatives) and local SCF-US staff to identify the neediest women-headed households. These mechanisms will identify the neighborhoods of greatest destruction and/or poverty. SCF-US organizers will work in pairs of one man and one woman, to promote women's participation and assess the volume of reconstruction work (number of houses multiplied by the estimated percentage of destruction). These organizers will also ensure, through spot visits and other means, that the beneficiaries are indeed village residents, and that they have not received any free construction materials in the past three years. 11. SCF-US staff then calculate the food and material requirements. The material requirements are calculated according to the annexed Technical Note 1, and the food requirements according to the annexed Technical Note 2. 12. Village brigades are formed (usually 15-20 persons), from the community members. Each brigade elects a leader, and a detailed contract is formalized between SCF-US and the brigades (including terms and conditions, details of each house owner and work to be done, and names of the brigade members). Usually the brigade leader enters into a contract with the village executive committee for the provision of transport. The establishing of such a relationship is hoped to encourage the extension of official participation to include further negotiated contributions from their own resources towards minor repair works of community benefit (e.g. repair of street lights). 13. Roofing materials (tiles and timber) will be procured by International Competitive Bidding, except for the requirements for the first two hundred houses which will be procured by Direct Contract and International Shopping respectively. The materials will remain under SCF-US control from receipt to delivery upon the brigade's completion of preparatory reconstruction work (to wall-plate level). The delivery of the materials and food is authorized upon receipt of a satisfactory post-survey report prepared by SCF-US. The brigade is responsible for organizing the transport and distribution of the items to the respective beneficiaries. This process is rigorously monitored and documented fully by SCF-US. 14. Food is released and distributed according to specified procedures against work done (historical average is 210 kg. of food per house, consisting of 90 kg. wheat flour, 90 kg. beans, and 30 kg. edible oil). House construction is seasonal (March to November), and food distributed for completed housing is targeted to reach the beneficiaries during the most critical pre-harvest period of food shortages. (Note: SCF-US's FFW activities continue for canal cleaning and war rubble clearance during the non- construction period of the year under a program financed by USDA independently of this Shelter program. 15. In order to demonstrate the technology and determine training needs, three demonstration houses were roofed with tiles prior to project start-up, to demonstrate the effectiveness of the tiles. Site visits and training will be arranged for a small number of selected community representatives and government officials from other parts of the country where there is an identified housing need (i.e. rural Penjikent, Aini, Mascho), with a view to building capacity in other local organizations for similar programs.

ENVIRONMENTAL ASPECTS 20. The project rehabilitates ruined structures in existing habitations, where families are returning to their former houses. The result is significant improvement in the built environment, with no adverse impacts on the natural environment. SUSTAINABILITY 21. Sustainability of impact is built into the project, as the significant improvements to shelter would remove a key constraint to income generation for poor families and enable them to concentrate on productive investment of time; it would also have a positive impact on family health and therefore on productivity by reducing overcrowding and improving living conditions. 22. Sustainability of process is limited. The project strategy is a "rehabilitation" mode, mid-way between relief and development, and is facilitated by external provision of food for work and building materials. In some cases work groups have continued on their own dynamic, and they often participate in further poverty alleviation and reconstruction activities (e.g. Group Guaranteed Lending, canal cleaning

The activity of reconstruction in Tajikistan depends almost entirely on external provision of food for work, and scarce reconstruction materials. Unless the project continues, the remaining deficit of 4,000 houses, together with those of newly returned families, will only very gradually be rehabilitated. 23.  - 54 - ANNEX C REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN PILOT POVERTY ALLEVIATION PROJECT MICRO-CREDIT PROGRAM (SAVE THE CHILDREN-US) SUMMARY 1. The proposed program will focus on women in war-affected regions of Tajikistan to achieve in two years the following specific objectives: (a) provide access to credit and mobilize savings for 3, 750 women in the Bokhtar, Vaksh, Vose, Kurgan-Tube and Kolkhozabad districts of Khatlon Region; (b) generate additional income for 3750 people in the Bokhtar, Vaksh, Vose, Kurgan Tube and Kolkhozabad districts of Khatlon Region; (c) positively impact approximately 18,750 children and other dependents of the original 3750 borrowers; (d) develop the Group Guaranteed Loans and Savings (GGLS) program into an independent local NGO or financial services institution that can operate independently within four years a micro finance program that sustains access capital for poor women. The program is currently operating in Kurgan-Tube, Bokhtar, Vaksh and Kolkhozabad districts of Western Khatlon. The proposed expanded GGLS program will include Vose District. The existing program has been operating for over one year. The expanded program will be for a period of two years and will begin in April 1997 and continue until April 1999. It will be implemented by Save the Children-US. OBJECTIVES 2. Over 800,000 people were displaced from the war in 1992-93. The homes of more than 25,000 families were destroyed and those who fled lost all or most of their productive and household assets. The 800,000 displaced, particularly the 25,000 families who lost their homes, constitute the largest single vulnerable group in Tajikistan today. In addition areas like Khulyab face extreme lack of economic opportunities. Particularly poorer section of the community are facing extreme hardship for their livelihood. It is crucial that they have the opportunity to reestablish their productivity. 3. The social, political and economic upheavals of the last few years have precipitated the final disintegration of an already dysfunctional institutional infrastructure. At present the Government of Tajikistan does not have comprehensive policies for civic groups or rural banking institutions, restricting the development of both. The presence of arbitrary and obstructive tax policies further restrict opportunities for people to create indigenous structures that would help protect and provide for themselves. Government is not able to provide access or education to encourage alternative sources for opportunities like small business development. Formal banks are not reliable and do not provide access to credit for poor women. The lack of collateral among poor women, returnee refugees and internally displaced people (IDPs) forces would-be entrepreneurs to enter high risk relationships for credit with black market lenders. Poor women, returnee refugees and IDPs have no institutional structure other than their equally depressed families and friends to assist on their livelihood. Most people receive little or no cash for the work they perform for the collective farms and businesses. Alternative sources of income and services are necessary for people to provide for their basic needs.
 - 55 - 4. The population now has a disproportionate gender and age composition. Many men were killed in the war leaving behind women, children and the elderly. Historically in Tajikistan men have the greater access to jobs for cash. However, the present circumstances create a great demand for capital among women. Without access to credit and an active earning member in the family, life for the remaining members has been very difficult. Even though women want to work to earn a living, they are limited in their income generating activities due to a dearth of skills. The expanded program will provide the essential capital for this otherwise alienated population through its proposed GGLS and provide technical support so that women can improve and broaden their skills. The specific objectives of the expanded program are the following: (a) Sustainable reduction of poverty through the provision of access to credit and mobilization of savings for 3,750 women in the Bokhtar, Vaksh, Vole, Kurgan-Tube and Kolkhozabad districts of Khatlon Region. (b) Generation of additional income for 3,750 people in the Bokhtar, Vaksh, Vose, Kurgan Tube and Kolkhozabad Districts of Khatlon Region. (c) Positive impact on approximately 18,750 children and other dependents of the original 3,750 borrowers. (d) Development of the GGLS program into an independent local NGO or financial services institution that can operate independently within four years a micro finance program that sustains access capital for poor women. (e) Development of common ground and bringing people together for their mutual benefit. STRATEGY AND TARGETING 5. The current strategy focuses on construction brigades and women's committees. SCF-US will allocate to each group loan money from its revolving fund budget. The group will approve its members' loans on the basis of the feasibility of the economic activities proposed by the applicant, and the group's judgement of the applicant's ability to implement the proposed activities and repay the loan. As there is no collateral in the group lending program, therefore the group will guarantee repayment if the borrower in its group defaults. If a group does not repay the loan when it is due that group's access to the loan money will be cut off or be suspended until and unless due repayment is made. Groups that perform well will receive more loan fund allocations from the GGLS program. As the group gains experience and performs well, the amount of subsequent individual loans will increase as individuals develop their entrepreneurial capacity. 11. Savings will be an important component of the program. Saving serves as an indicator of profit and commitment. The GGLS program will require clients to save on a weekly basis, which will total three percent of the loan in a cycle. However, program participants will be encouraged to save more. Group savings perform many functions, including servicing as a guarantee for defaults and being available for future capital expansion. Group participants will be encouraged to open individual or group saving accounts once the banking facilities will be available in the working area. The Micro Credit Group Guarantee Loans and Savings program aims to develop the existing program into a sustainable local NGO or financial services institution that can operate independently within four years and can sustain the access to capital for poor women. Within two years from the start date of this upscaled project a core group of borrowers and GGLS staff will begin participating in SC sponsored training and will produce an agenda for the development of a local apex institution that can fully operate a micro credit program within four years. Various operating responsibilities related to the GGLS program will be handed over to the clients groups through the four year period as their capacity dictates. In the fourth year of this program groups receiving credit and savings services will be managed and monitored by this apex NGO. Furthermore, in the fourth year of this program the apex NGO will be provided a one time grant to run the credit and savings program and establish links to other organizations so that its members can access more resources. The GGLS program will also be linked, through the monitoring and evaluation process, to the TASIF according to the operational manual guidelines. This will enable a strengthening of institutional replicability and sustainability. To address the issue of financial sustainability, savings will be an important component of the project. Savings serves as an indicator of profit and commitment as well as sustainability. The GGLS program will require clients to save on a weekly basis which will total 3% of the loan in a cycle. Group savings perform many functions, including serving as a guarantee for defaults and being available for future capital expansion. Group members will be encouraged to open individual or group savings accounts once the banking facilities are available in the area. All 3750 group members will get loans in 3 month cycles. At the close of the first year of the project 3450 loans will be disbursed to 1500 members. Disbursed loans will be protected by 100 groups, averaging 15 members per group. In the first and second quarter of the first year 20 groups each will enter the first loan cycle. Similarly in the second year 30 groups each will enter the first loan cycle. Similarly, in the second year 30 groups each in first and second quarters and 45 groups each in last two quarters will join the first cycle of loan. Upon the successful completion of a loan cycle in the end of each quarter groups will enter a new loan cycle and will remain constant once they reach the fourth cycle. Repayments of loan with interest from the first year will be revolved for continued funding in subsequent years. the proposed loan funding will allow all groups to reach the forth loan cycle and continue receiving loans indefinitely provided additional funding is secured to pay portion of the program costs. SCF estimates the program will be 6 % operationally self sustainable a the end of the first year and 27%, 72% and 144% at the end of the second, third and fourth years respectively with standard interest charge of 10% to which 3% will be added to make the total service charge 13%. However the 3% will be deposited in groups names and will remain as the savings for the group. Groups will have full authority in the utilization of the savings fund.

 - 67 - ANNEX D REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN PILOT POVERTY ALLEVIATION PROJECT PROGRAM OF SUPPORT TO FEMALE-HEADED HOUSEHOLDS (SAVE THE CHILDREN UK) SUMMARY 1. The proposed program will focus on female-headed households in Western Tajikistan (Vaksh, Aini, Panjkent, Dushanbe and Shaartuz Districts). It will assist 3,700 of the most vulnerable households, and build the capacity of up to 16 local organizations by providing practical experience in effective approaches to poverty alleviation. The program will have two components: (1) Support to Vulnerable Households in Khatlon Province, which will reach 2,100 female-headed households with agricultural inputs and social services; and (2) Capacity Building for Poverty Alleviation, which will strengthen 16 local government and non governmental organizations and reach up to 1,600 female-headed households with appropriate community-centered poverty alleviation activities. OBJECTIVES 2. Levels of household poverty are high and increasing through out Tajikistan, and the most vulnerable groups are suffering the direct consequences in ill health, poor nutrition, inadequate housing and lost opportunities for education. Household incomes have fallen as a result of dramatically reduced opportunities for employment and access to resources for self employment is very limited. Compounding the problem of household poverty is the collapse of the basic health and education services, due to the central government's inability to finance them adequately. Access to health care for the poorest has been severely curtailed by the rising cost of treatment as well as supply shortages. Local response to this situation is hampered by the lack of experience and capacity within both local government and NGOs to understand and respond to the needs of vulnerable households. This is due in part to a inadequate knowledge and skills concerning practical approaches to poverty alleviation among staff of local government and NGOs. 3. In Khatlon Province, the Districts of Vaksh and Bokhtar, where SCF (UK) has been working since 1994, were among those most seriously affected by the civil war. There are a large number of vulnerable households - many of which are female headed and thus face considerable social as well as economic obstacles. SCF's experience in the area indicates the importance of addressing all these issues, including in particular the decline in educational and child care services, and the need for access to other social services. 4. The objectives of the project are ensure that a total of 3,700 most vulnerable households gain access agriculture assets and social services such as day-care centers and schools, and to build local capacity of 16 local organizations to deliver such services. The project consists of two main components:
 - 68 - Component 1: Support to Vulnerable Households in Khatlon Province 5. This component builds on the experience of SCF (UK) in working with female-headed households in Bokhtar/Vaksh districts, and has the following objectives: * to increase levels of household income for 2,100 vulnerable households by July 1999, through the provision of agricultural assets such as livestock, seeds and tools as well as technical advice; * to strengthen local capacity to support day-care centers and schools serving 30 villages, by establishing community based mechanisms for the management of grants and revolving funds generated by agriculture inputs; * to promote access to available services and resources through the dissemination of information and advice, group formation, and legal support to vulnerable h households indirectly to the population of 30 villages. Component 2: Capacity Building for Poverty Alleviation 6. In order to start extending poverty alleviation activities beyond Khatlon province, and to test the applicability of project approaches in other circumstances the aim of this component is: C to enable up to 1600 vulnerable households in four areas of the country to achieve higher levels of self reliance and greater access to income support; * to improve the capacity of selected local organizations (government and non-government) to identify and support appropriate community centered poverty alleviation activities. STRATEGY AND TRAINING 7. The program will provide productive assets to individual female-headed households, in order to improve household food security and, where possible, generate a family income through the sale of produce. SCF's experience indicates that this approach can be successful, provided that support appropriate and based upon adequate consultation with beneficiaries about the scale of assistance and the nature of assets to be provided. The introduction of a revolving fund element makes such participation even more important. 8. It has also become apparent that to achieve sustained impact across the full range of problems faced by vulnerable households, poverty alleviation activities must also address social and other non- economic obstacles, and that this requires support to organization at the community level over a period of years rather then months. Community level organization is the major challenge in introducing this approach in other areas. 9. While continuing to ensure the appropriateness of material inputs distributed to individual households, SCF (UK) will seek ways to improve the overall quality of the productive assets provided. In rural areas this will include research into the feasibility of introducing improved wheat and potato seed
 - 69 - (particularly imported varieties). Different approaches will be developed in urban districts covered under the local capacity building component. 10. Field staff will play a critical role in all project activities, through informing vulnerable families about their rights as well as about existing services and assistance programs. For example, experience has shown that explaining the land reform process and the mechanisms for applying for land, as well as following up on households requests for land with local and national authorities, can result in significant benefits. ACTIVITIES Component 1: Support to Vulnerable households in Khatlon Province: 11. In Vaksh District, SCF(UK) will identify 30 villages with a high proportion of vulnerable (particularly FHH) households. These villages will be located around local schools and day-care centers. Based on the level of productive assets and social conditions of each household SCF (UK) will classify vulnerable families according to criteria which have been developed for the ongoing project. 12. By the end of July 1997, two lists of FHHs will be identified by SCF field workers. The initial 700 FHH will form groups of 20 to 30 households. Each household will receive productive assets according to their level of need up to a maximum equivalent to $150 per household. All households will receive inputs on condition that they undertake to repay the equivalent value in cash or kind. The repayment rate will be set at between 100 and 120 percent over a period to be determined by the SCF (UK) depending on local conditions. 13. Most of the funds repaid will be used to provide similar assistance to the second list of 700 FHHs, and as these receive their material inputs, a third group of up to 700 vulnerable households (some of which may not be female headed) will be identified to receive assistance once further funds are available. 14. Any balance of repaid funds will be provided to local schools or day-care centers. These funds will be managed by a committee including representatives of vulnerable households, other parents, pupils, teachers and local authorities. The committees will be supported by an SCF (UK) field worker. 15. Support to schools and day-care centers will also include one-off grants (possibly in the form of food for work for staff) as well as assistance in the formation of community management boards and in the continuing management of income from he local revolving funds. 16. An integral part of all this work will be the dissemination of information. Field workers will promote group formation, provide advice and legal support, and help to mediate with local authorities and service providers. Component 2: Capacity building for Poverty Alleviation 17. This component will develop practical skills among staff of local government and non-government organizations. It is expected that these organizations will work at the community level to assist vulnerable families in the identification of pilot projects which focus on income generation and improved access to essential services.

The program aims to deliver rapid support to vulnerable households, as well as to build the capacity of local institutions to provide such support in the future.  -76 - ANNEX E REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN PILOT POVERTY ALLEVIATION PROJECT AGRICULTURAL REFORM PROGRAM (AGA KHAN FOUNDATION) SUMMARY 1. The Agricultural Reform Program (ARP) is being implemented by the Pamir Relief and Development Program (PRDP) in collaboration with the Aga Khan Foundation (AKF) in the Gorno- Badakhshan Autonomous Oblast (GBAO), the mountainous region of eastern Tajikistan. Since its inception in 1993, the program has grown more rapidly than anticipated, and PRDP has specific plans for its significant expansion in the next few years in the areas irrigation and new land development. In 1997/1998 ARP will complete the construction of 32 gravity-flow irrigation channels (107 kilometers) in six of GBAO's seven districts'' which will enable the cultivation of 3,877 hectares of new privately managed land. Some 1,600 small resource farmers will participate. PRDP will provide technical advice along with provision of improved seed, fertilizer, and other inputs on credit. In addition, the program will furnish resources for PRDP's expansion through the development of district offices of the NGO. OBJECTIVES 2. Due to geo-political reasons, the region of GBAO has always been isolated from much of the rest of Tajikistan. In spite of its isolation, the Soviets did establish an extensive system of collective (kolkhoz) and state (sovkhoz) farms with centralized management. With little arable land and misguided decisions of central planners, however, GBAO was heavily dependent upon imports from other regions of the Soviet Union, and 80% of needed foodstuffs was brought in annually. After the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, the residents of GBAO faced severe hardship and a widespread system of humanitarian food distribution was established by the Aga Khan Foundation (AKF). This continues today. The major needs of the populace are the provision of food, along with the creation of employment opportunities. Some 80% of the labor force is estimated to be unemployed. It is in this context that the Agricultural Reform Program is especially relevant. 3. By charter, AKF is a development institution and not a relief organization. Thus in 1992 it established the first local NGO in GBAO, the PRDP (Pamir Relief and Development Program), which has been active in increasing the production and productivity of the region's agricultural sector through the ARP, along with continuing its humanitarian assistance. 1/ These districts include Darwaz, Vanch, Rushan, Shugnan, Roshtkala, and Ishkashim; only the district of Murghab is excluded because its populace is largely pastoral.
 - 77 - 4. The long-term goal of the ARP is to establish self-sufficiency in and reliance upon staple food crops in GBAO through the fostering of increased efficiency and intensification of land use in an environmentally sound way throughout the region. The basic objectives involved in the expansion of ARP in GBAO for the coming years of 1997-1998 are as follows: 1. To expand the area under food crop production; 2. To increase food crop production and productivity; 3. To establish and support private farm management; 4. To develop human and institutional capacity in agriculture. 5. The major targets to be achieved in the coming years include the following: 1997 1998 TOTAL # channel systems completed (within year) 19 13 32 # kilometers of channels completed (within year) 31.8 km 76.0 km 107.8 km # hectares of land brought under cultivation (within year) 325 ha 627 ha 952 ha # hectares of land to be brought under culti- vation by 2004 3,877 ha 6. Focus will be upon small resource farmers throughout GBAO. Assuming that 1,600 farmers are included in the program by 1998, and with an average family size of 8 persons, a total of 12,800 individuals will directly benefit from this expansion of ARP. The improvement in crop production and the corresponding development of markets will in turn help all consumers of agricultural products in the participating rural communities and in the region in general. STRATEGY AND TARGETING 7. PRDP works only with farmers who want to become (or have become) private farmers. Private ownership of land is not important, but private management is. PRDP motivates farmers to negotiate with the Government of GBAO for land (both previously cultivated and new plots) and assists them in negotiating with kolkhoz authorities and district officials in order to obtain formal written contracts for
 - 78 - private management which define and guarantee land access rights.z' Subsequently PRDP helps private farmers by providing agricultural inputs (improved seed, fertilizer, and fuel) on credit, along with technical advice and assistance in cropping and irrigation. 8. Since ARP began, villagers' first and foremost concern has been the need to bring additional lands under cultivation in GBAO.3' Thus the NGO decided to assist farmers in channel construction and new land development. The specific strategy is as follows: * Villagers desiring PRDP assistance in channel construction and new land development must first come together, agree to work on the channel, and discuss their plans. * The farmers form a group and elect a sardar (leader) who will be the primary negotiator with both government and PRDP. * The group prepares a formal written request to the government. The sardar then negotiates with the government officials and obtains permission in writing for the farmers in his group to utilize the designated unused lands for private management once the channel is completed. * The PRDP Agronomy Supervisor must then visit the proposed new land and ascertain that it has suitable potential for cultivation. The PRDP Irrigation Engineer must also visit the land, ascertain that the channel construction is feasible, and calculate its cost. * PRDP finally signs a formal agreement with the farmers' group stating that it will help with channel construction and land development (i.e. technical assistance and materials). * Villagers agree to provide all manual labor required for channel construction, which is fostered by Food-For-Work financed by GTZ. 9. PRDP does not target the poor per se. At present individual village households and communities are quite homogenous in their needs and, as noted above, all of the residents of GBAO face severe hardships. If, with time, communities and/or households become more stratified economically, PRDP will re-examine its policy. 2/ The specific PRDP-related agricultural reform processes in the area of farm restructuring are consistent with the National Government's land reform and farm restructuring program that is currently being implemented on a pilot basis in other parts of the country and is supported by IDA's Agricultural Recovery and Social Production Credit . 3/ At present a total of approximately 13,000 hectares of land in GBAO is under cultivation, which include both kolkhoz plots and PRDP-assisted privately managed lands. Grain yields from these fields fall far short of the necessary 30,000 metric tons of wheat annually required for GBAO, however, and rations continue to be distributed to all of the populace with AKF assistance. An estimated 10,000 hectares of potential land for cultivation exists throughout the region which presently lack irrigation sources. Although of varying quality, some 4,000-6,000 hectares exhibit very good potential for wheat, barley, alfalfa, and potatoes.

To expand the area under food crop production: Activities: a. increase the amount of land under food crop production; b. establish new irrigation systems; c. establish an intensive cropping system; d. use Food-For-Work for irrigation channel construction and new land development. 2. To increase food crop production and productivity: Activities: a. supply agricultural inputs (improved seed, fertilizer, and fuel) on credit; b. foster high-quality seed multiplication and seed distribution between farmers. 3. To establish and support private farm management: Activities: a. upgrade competence among farmers in negotiating with kolkhoz directors; b. establish private farm management; c. assist in establishing an open market and encourage sale of surplus produce. 4. To develop human and institutional capacity in agriculture: Activities: a. train PRDP staff to help private farmers negotiate agreements with the Government for private use of land, conduct irrigation activities; provide assistance in land development; b. train farmers in resource (water) and crop management. ENVIRONMENTAL ASPECTS 23. PRDP's activities are being implemented in an environmentally sound way. Staff is clearly aware of the fragile nature of the Pamir ecosystem, and they act accordingly. The proposed ARP will not have adverse effects upon the enviroinent: * The small gravity-flow irritation channels will result in only the re-routing of water, which will then flow into the same mountain rivers as prior to channel construction. * Trees and other vegetation will grow along the channels (as encouraged by PRDP), and these "vegetative breaks" will help to stop erosion. * Channels such as these have been similarly constructed in GBAO for centuries, and both the local populace and PRDP engineers/agriculturalists are well-versed in the technology. * Land to be brought under cultivation is not on the mountain-sides but rather on the edges of existing fields and in valleys. * No displacement of communities will be involved. * The project will give farmers even more incentive to manage water sources carefully in a stress environment and encourages group formation and participation at the village level.

A Social Assessment (SA) was been undertaken in order better to understand the nature and causes of poverty, its dynamics, and the context in which effective solutions may be developed. Although the SA is best seen as a process of investigation, its central part is a field investigation conducted in May- June 1996 in seven selected sites, to address the following key questions: Poverty Profre: 3 Who is poor, where, how and why? Livelihood strategies: 3 What are people doing? 3 How to meet their basic needs? Elements for a response: * What are local priority needs for poverty alleviation? 3 What is local capacity to organize for development? 3 What is the community assessment of existing NGO programs? 3 What are the implications for a Social Investment Fund? 2. The field study method was based on Participatory Rapid Appraisal which seeks to document local knowledge of problems and their solutions. Qualitative research was chosen in preference to quantitative methods at this stage, because the rapidly changing situation in Tajikistan requires an understanding of the dynamics of change before indicators can be developed for the study of quantitative aspects. 8/ The social assessment report was compiled and written by Ms E. Gomart, consultant to the World Bank, who also trained and led the research team and analyzed the results of their findings. A research team of 11 Tajik nationals undertook five weeks of intensive field work in May-June 1996, working extremely long hours and displaying a high level of commitment, a willingness to learn new research techniques, and an ability to learn about conditions and trends in their country.  - 87 - POVERTY PROFILE A. Background 3. Even before the war, Tajikistan was one of the poorest newly independent states of the former Soviet Union. It inherited low levels of investment, an imbalanced pattern of industrialization, high dependency on imported food, and weak social indicators (high malnutrition rates, low school attendance of girls in most rural areas, high unemployment). Since independence in 1991, chronic poverty was rapidly worsened both by the collapse of the union economy and by the civil war which caused an estimated 25,000 deaths and 600,000 refugees and displaced people--mostly from Kurgan Tube region. Although the civil war is said to have ended in October 1993, fighting erupts periodically and opposition forces are active in the central-eastern part of the country: in the Garm Valley, and the pre-Pamir districts of Darwaz and Vanj. 4. Most households have been hard hit hard by the civil war and protracted political and economic crises. As a result, security and rule of law are main priorities for the population. There is a widespread desire for peace, for an end to forced conscription, improved security and increased rule of law. Political and military meddling by outsiders is seen as a main impediment to normalization. Most people believe peace may be achieved either by the coming to power of a third neutral political party, or by a coalition government that will bring together all political factions. B. Who are the Poor? 5. Some communities identified three socio-economic strata: the poorest households, those who were average, and the rich. Other communities were more sharply divided between a few well-to-do families and the rest of the population who were "spending their days running after a piece of bread". Some effort was required to overcome initial reluctance to reveal socio-economic distinctions within a community, and to cope with local perceptions of the possible motives of outside researchers. 6. Informants identified the poor as those who, through a combination of adverse factors, are struggling to put bread on the table. The poor are those who in the past relied the most on allowances and other forms of subsidies during the Soviet Union. Poor families tend to have no working man; many children (eight or more); no land, or just a small area often planted only with wheat; insufficient agricultural inputs; and poor state of health. The poor include those families who rely overly on salaries from the kolkhoz (i.e. the man works on the kolkhoz), social services or unskilled labor (e.g. cleaner).
 - 88 - 7. The middle stratum of society includes those people who need to work hard and use all their resources to make ends meet. They usually have at least two males of working age, and thus, in comparison to poor families, have a higher ratio of males compared to females, children and elderly. These families also have access to land which they are cultivating. They may hold two or more cows (or one cow, plus sheep or goats). Cash remittances from family members working elsewhere are important. Within this group, the households that are doing rather better are those that have a resource cushion which they have been able to accumulate or to preserve. This cushion consists of savings (e.g. cattle or capital), or productive assets (e.g. orchards or equipment) which allow the household to survive a period of adversity. By contrast, most people who find themselves towards the bottom of this middle stratum are conscious of the risk that they may fall into poverty. They are relatively poor and are able to meet only the most basic food and clothing needs. The solutions that they have found to their problems are vulnerable to being nullified at any time by corruption, insecurity, and market fluctuations. 8. In general, the rich are those who have a link to the management of local industries, to local or regional government, or to the security forces. In towns and large district centers, respondents perceived that the rich gain a living not so much from their work itself, but through benefits obtained by virtue of their position of employment. Another source of wealth is large remittances from Russia. C. Local Criteria of Poverty 9. Communities identified the following indicators of relative poverty between households. These are: * inability to provide basic household needs: food, shelter, shoes, health, education; * no labor, or insufficient labor, available at household level; * depletion of assets (cattle, personal property); * lack of access to productive assets; * lack of employment; and * lack of ties to the local ruling clan D. Basic Needs 10. Many households were not able to satisfy more than basic food needs. The quality and quantity of food available was usually assessed by the type of bread available for household consumption, since bread quality corresponds closely to household incomes and access to cash and markets. This spring (1996) many households had to eke out scarce supplies of wheat flour by mixing it with other grains-- maize, and even hay and cotton seeds. Some families had no wheat flour at all, and were using flour which they made only from hay or other grasses. A few infants were said to have died of hunger in the villages in the week preceding the survey, and many adults and children were extremely thin and faint with hunger.
 - 89 - 11. Shelter is a need that cannot be met by many resettled households who have few assets and sources of cash income. Shelter is also a problem for young families, and results in overcrowding in single rooms and on plots for single households. 12. The lack of children's shoes is the most often cited obstacle to school attendance. After food, shoes are the next the main cash purchase that poor families make. Clothes are also needed among recently displaced or resettled families who often have left their homes empty-handed. 13. Poor access to health services was also an indicator of poverty, both because it implies reduced capacity to generate income, and because it is associated with poor nutrition. Health services are increasingly out of reach for the poor. Not only are medicines routinely sold, but doctors--especially in towns--are charging for their services. In villages, doctors have so few resources that treatment is commonly unavailable. The poor reported that increasingly doctors are turning away poor patients because they cannot pay for care. As a result, most families try to turn to tabibs, traditional healers who are found in most villages and towns. 14. Poor access to education is linked to low incomes, as demonstrated through the lack of shoes, winter clothes, supplies, transportation and reliance on incomes earned by children. Poor education uptake also derives from the declining value of education in the eyes of parents, and to tradition which limits attendance of girls over the age of 11. In urban areas, where schools collect money for repairs, fees are also increasingly being charged by teachers. The exodus of teachers and decreased attendance of teachers during the school day also jeopardizes the quality of education. E. Labor power 15. Labor power is literally manpower, and refers to the number of healthy, grown men capable of providing for the household. The criterion speaks to the felt reality of female-headed households: * women without husbands often lack the confidence to request officials for land, nor do they receive the respect which would lead to the request's being granted; * strong workers are needed to clear boulders from reclaimed land; * the more male adults compared to the rest of the members of the household, the better off the household; * work in the CIS is mostly physical work, such as construction and agricultural work, which requites strong, healthy men. 16. Manpower is threatened by forced conscription which keeps many young men out of the markets and the fields, and by continued insecurity in areas of former conflict, which impedes the return of husbands and grown men to these areas. F. Depletion of assets 17. Cattle holdings in rural areas are a store for wealth. There is occurring throughout the country a rapid and dramatic decline in cattle holdings of formerly "average" (two-cow) families, meaning a
 - 90 - depletion of household savings. Cattle are being sold more rapidly than the rate of natural replacement in order to purchase flour (especially during the spring) and medicines. 18. The poor, especially displaced and resettled families and Russian pensioners in towns, are selling their personal belongings, including refrigerator, furniture, dishes, blankets, and even the wooden floor planks. G. Lack of access to productive assets 19. Most people hope to cultivate land as a viable local source of income. Land use and leasing is accorded by law to all rural residents. Land leases are meant to be long-term, with the crop to be determined by the individual lease-holder. However, in practice access to land is determined less by residence and more by other factors including: manpower in the household; profession (kolkhoz worker, farm management, teacher or doctor); regional-ethnic group; availability of resources for cultivation; quality, and distance of land relative to place of residence; and access to markets. Access to land and the ability to cultivate it are often reserved for the well-to-do. 20. The type of cultivation on household plots is a good indicator of resources available for income generation and access to markets. Cultivation of presidential land which varies greatly in terms of quality, distance from the village, water supply, etc., can also provide a view into resources -- material or political to secure and cultivate a favorable plot. The type of land lease obtained by the household may also reveal its standing within the kolkhoz. The common kolkhoz worker commonly receives one- year lease for a comparatively small area (e.g. 1-5 hectares, or 100 apple trees) with a predetermined crop, and a price to be determined on an individual basis at the time of harvest. The well-to-do lease- holder receives a long-term lease (5-10 years) for a comparatively large area (5 to 600 hectares) with no predetermined crop. 21. Access to other types of productive assets such as equipment (tractors, trucks, buses and vans) is also a good indicator of wealth. Mostly tractors are owned by rural residents, while mechanized transportation, such as buses and vans, are rented from the city authority and require an agreement with the town to operate. H. Employment 22. In both urban and rural areas an important criteria of poverty is employment--not only its access but its type. Heads of households working in the collective farm were considered the poorest. Doctors and especially teachers in villages were also seen as poor. Those with employment which provides access to materials and products that can be used or sold on the market were considered the best off--these included enterprise, farm and government officials. Salaries also vary greatly between sectors. For example, one farm director earns TR 13,000, and a policeman in Shakhristan, Leninabad region, was said to make TR 20,000 per month, while the local teacher made on average TR 1,200.
 - 91 - I. Ties to the local ruling clan 23. Access to resources for wealth may be a function of membership in a localized clan. Such clans may dominate entire bureaucracies at the local and regional levels. The case of the village of Galadzor in Vose was striking. One village consisted of "foreigners" originally from Hovalling. It was systematically disadvantaged in relation to neighboring Vose-originated villages in the rest of the kolkhoz, in respect of land distribution, availability of pasture land and employment opportunities as hired labor. J. Predisposing Characteristics: Rural, War-affected, and Isolated. 24. Based on the above criteria we can conclude that three main characteristics render certain areas liable to poverty: a rural situation, in contrast to an urban one; war-affected villages, and isolated villages. 25. Urban areas are less vulnerable to poverty because they present opportunities for employment as well as access to markets. The poverty of some urban households may be no less deep than that of rural ones, but it is less widespread. The most vulnerable in towns are Russians, and single pensioners, and female-headed households without a bread winner. Among the poorest urban households were also those headed by unemployed, unskilled men. War affected villages are most at risk from: - a high proportion of female-headed families with low levels of man power and poor access to land; e low levels of savings (cattle) that act as a buffer against hunger; i low nutritional status because of lack of means for cultivating cash crops, eroded assets (cattle, personal goods), resulting in poor health status; * poor condition or lack of shelter because of destruction related to the war and erosion of savings (construction materials, cash); * discrimination and lack of security which inhibits growth and affects particularly those originally from Garm and the Pamirs; * low level of attendance of schools owing to low incomes and fear of reprisals. 26. Isolated villages which are located over 10 km from an active market or which do not have a tradition of cultivating cash crops have been hard hit hard by price increases and by the decrease in real value of salaries. The situation was caused by the following factors: * Land problems: non-use of Presidential Land; lack of access to leased land; squeezing of small farmers off irrigated land by large lease-holders, and from access to pasture lands * rapidly decreasing level of cattle holdings
 - 92 - * lack of cultivation for market sales * low level of access to education: affecting mostly girls over 12 * low level of health services provided in villages 27. In these villages, a solution to the problem was not immediately visible and contributed to the feeling of hopelessness. LIVELIHOOD STRATEGIES 28. How do households and individuals cope with these problems? Throughout the different sites, several trends were identified: decreased consumption levels diversification of income sources (away from salaries, and toward land cultivation) increased participation of all members of the household (women, children) increased incidence of begging for and stealing of food products. 29. Some strategies are common to all situations, while others are more specific to different situations.

Common Livelihood Strategies 30. Lower consumption: Reduced consumption is a strategy that has been adopted by the great majority of households in Tajikistan to live through this crisis. Reduction in consumption has limited expenditures ancd consumption of home produced goods to the basics. Food quantity and quality has been affected. The use of corn or hay for bread, mentioned above, is one example. Households also reduce purchases such as meat, oil and sugar to under 10 per cent of their budget. Ceremonies--such as weddings and funerals--have also been curtailed so that poor families can conduct them. 31. Support networks: Networks of support are very effective, whether these are based on relatives or a wider community or neighborhood. For example one pensioner living alone in Dushanbe said that she relied on her neighbors and relatives for 80 percent of her needs. Within households, the work force
 - 94 - as well as income are commonly pooled, making use of economies of scale and attempting to lower the dependency ratio. In rural areas, all members of the household, including women and children, participate in production. 32. Humanitarian assistance is an essential source of food for poor households in the war-affected areas and in Gorno Badakhshan. 33. Remittances are a strategy common to both urban and rural areas with a tradition of sending men abroad for seasonal jobs. It remains the main strategy for alleviating local unemployment, especially among young men. Access to this strategy requires the following: a large village or nearby center to facilitate transportation; a network of ethnic or regional contacts in the CIS; a local tradition of seasonal labor; and some capital for placement fee, transport and initial expenses. While remittances provide the main source of income to build up savings, to purchase assets and to rehabilitate war-affected villages, they do not provide a reliable source of income to cover daily expenses, leaving families sometimes at risk. B. Livelihood Strategies in Villages 34. Land provides the most reliable source of income to rural households. However access to sufficient land and essential inputs is limited. As a result, grain production from Presidential land and household plots satisfies the needs of the household for only 3-6 months of the year. Consequently, households need to diversify production to more lucrative produce which can be exchanged for grain. Cash crops were principally sold in small amounts because of difficulties with transport and physical security. Land leases, as seen previously, do not necessarily provide a good source of income. As a result, farmers are also informally cultivating land: by planting pasture land, and by double-cropping on leased land. For example, wheat is planted in leased orchards. 35. Cattle sales is the main livelihood strategy of the poor in mountainous and isolated villages, although it depletes a major asset. For those who are able to manage sales in such a way as to avoid this danger, cattle trade can be an excellent source of income. 36. Markets: Town markets are a place where rural residents sell home-produced fruits, vegetables, milk products or meat either directly, or in bulk to a trader. Access to market is a is influenced by: * security; * distances between the village and the nearest market; * local production and demand for home produced goods; * costs of production and marketing; * gender; and * access to transport (cart, tractor, truck).
 - 95 - 37. In villages there are no proper markets. Urban based middlemen sometimes come to buy produce in villages with trucks or cars. Itinerant salesmen also go from house to house to sell or barter goods. 38. Trade and self-employment in villages consists of petty trade stalls, mostly operated by children and young women; production of crafts and other sewing (women); renting out of machinery; and private trading in cattle. Skilled labor in villages, such as carpenters, has additional opportunities for earning incomes either locally or in other CIS countries. Unskilled labor from the villages travels to the towns to compete for odd-jobs, or to work the land of large lease-holders. These opportunities are few and far between, and cannot be a reliable source of income for a household. 39. Salaries, especially rural salaries, rarely provide an important proportion of household income. Already low, salaries have been considerably eroded by inflation, and in any case are rarely paid--in one site, the latest payment was in 1995, while in another there has been no payment since 1994. Yet farmers receive partial payments in kind. Small amounts of food, fuel wood or cotton stocks are the incentive to work. Additional income generation activities are also available through the farm such as silkworm production which is lucrative yet requires a lot of labor. Doctors and teachers receive such small salaries that they are commonly considered some of the poorest in the village. Town and farm officials on the other hand, as well as security or army personnel are well paid. 40. Gathering of medicinal herbs is an additional source of income, especially for pensioners and women. Yet it provides only small contributions to household income. 41. Begging and stealing are common among villagers. One pensioner estimated that begging in distant villages represents 15 percent of her income. Stealing food is another source of income which is increasing in importance especially in the spring when people have run out of food. This is sometimes done openly. Stealing fruit and other cash crops for sale at the market was also a main source of income during Soviet times. C. Livelihood Strategies in Towns 42. In towns the livelihood strategies differed greatly from those in the villages. The main trends in livelihood strategies in towns and district centers were: * diversifying income sources from the main salary to other cash sources; * holding more than one salaried job simultaneously; * acquiring equipment, transportation or using acquired skills; * involving all persons in the household in income generation (including children); * links to agricultural production 43. Salaried employment remains the preferred source of income for many urban residents, often being supplemented by other activities (such as trading), earnings from odd jobs, or from salaries from other formal employment.
 - 96 - 44. While many salaries are low and often unpaid, the following are incentives: * high salaries in certain industries or sectors (such as security); * access to equipment, fuel and raw materials for sale or private production; * associated privileges (housing, free utilities, kindergarten, polyclinic). 45. Others have lost out in the crisis of salaries, particularly: * teachers, health workers and other workers in social services; * unqualified labor; * workers in uncompetitive industries (i.e. those using raw materials purchased from abroad, producing low quality products at high costs). 46. Market activities: In the main towns, large markets attract goods from the surrounding area, and also from Dushanbe and neighboring countries. Markets are considered to be the main source of income for urban households. Most industry and social services employees were said to be also involved in market activities, usually in petty or small trade, before or after their working hours. 47. Access to the market is limited by: * physical insecurity, which limits the scale of activities; * military conscription, which keeps young men away from public places; * cost of access to market as formal and informal fees to be paid to officials; and * availability of start-up capital. 48. Petty trading, where the seller resells goods from the central market to secondary markets, provides only minimal amounts of daily income, depending on the scale of the operation. Usually all family members are involved, with the adults purchasing goods and the women and children selling. There is also small trade in goods stolen from factories or products made from materials obtained through the place of formal employment. One woman estimated that 60 per cent of her income derives from dresses she makes from materials stolen at the textile factory. Urban sellers also purchase agricultural products in bulk from villagers in town or go to nearby villages to purchase goods in bulk. This is a more viable source of income. 49. Medium-scale trading applies to products procured from nearby countries, such as CIS, central Asian republics, Pakistan, China, or the United Arab Emirates; or through intermediary markets such as Termez, Dushanbe and Ura Tube. Women tend to trade in clothes and household appliances and to travel by plane and bus for reasons of security. Men, on the other hand, tend to travel by road or rail and to trade mostly in bulk quantities of food and fuel. The main obstacle to scaling up trade is the need to secure protection and capital. As a result, certain groups are most likely to be involved in trading of
 - 97 - imported goods, either because they have access to capital (e.g. Urgut Uzbeks) or links to the security forces. 50. Wage Labor: Daily wage labor is common in cities. Near the bazaars, large groups of 40-50 men from the town or from the nearby villages stand around hoping for offers of work. Men working in factories also work as wage labor at week-ends or during their free time. Young boys and men also stand around with carts waiting for a job. PROJECT IMPLICATIONS A. Priorities, Resources and Opportunities The main priorities for poverty alleviation are: * Peace, security and rule of law; * Improved ability to meet basic needs: food shelter, shoes, health education; * Diversity of income sources; * Access to productive assets to increase self-sufficiency and the ability to produce tradeable goods. 51. Peace, security and the rule of law: The desire for peace was widely expressed across the sites surveyed. People believed that with peace, the economic and political situation would improve and so would physical security. Physical and psychological insecurity is felt most acutely in war-affected areas (Kurgan Tube and Garm) and by certain groups, namely Garmis and Pamiris. Women in these areas feel particularly vulnerable without husbands or grown men to protect them. More general feelings of insecurity, which were encountered in many regions from Shakhristan to GAO, also inhibit economic rehabilitation and economic exchange and development. Police and border guards often demand bribes or part of the produce being transported. Food security is adversely affected when armed men steal harvests. Peace might also enable the borders with Uzbekistan to be reopened, and bring increased market and job opportunities. The continued conflict and forced conscription also restricts the mobility of young men who avoid public places. The lack of rule of law has had a major impact on resource allocation, favoring ruling clans at the expense of others. 52. Ability to meet basic needs. To assist the many households throughout the country that are currently unable to meet their most basic food needs, the following types of activities are proposed: * Information dissemination about laws and regulations regarding resource allocation, especially privatization, in order to improve people's knowledge of their own rights; * Material inputs (e.g. seeds, water systems) to assist the poor effectively to exploit those resources to which they have access; * Material assistance to support families in meeting their immediate food and shelter needs;
 - 98 - Development of cash crops and other marketable products through the provision of capital and material inputs to improve household incomes and therefore access to staples (flour) and other cash-based needs. 53. Diversification of sources of income. Diversification of household incomes from dependence on inadequate salaries towards inclusion of an array of in-kind and cash incomes is the main trend in livelihood strategies. It can be effectively supported through small-scale savings and credit schemes targeted to the poor. 54. Improved access to productive assets, such as land and cattle, is central to enable the poor to provide for their own needs. Asset allocation that consciously enables their access by the poor, along with support for the necessary inputs, will permit a more effective exploitation of these resources. A key requirement is a system of allocation and access that provides long-term security of use and encourages long-term investment. B. Local Institutions, Informal and Formal 55. Local institutions are structures within which local resources for development can be mobilized. Institutions working effectively to support households and communities are for the most part informal, traditional, male dominated, and based on family relations or locality, and often have a religious element. Formal institutions, such as the Women's Councils or Youth League, are center-based, hierarchical and top-down. The survey found that the presence and activities of the formal institutions in local communities was not always as great as their representatives believed. Despite their limitations, a locally- based participatory poverty alleviation strategy will have to take account of the limitations and potentials of both informal and formal institutions and either work through them or at least ensure their passive support. 56. The extended family network, in a patriarchal society, centers on the male head of household, his household and that of his sons. The clan which is based both on family and locality, includes the immediate relatives of the male head of household. 57. Neighborhood networks, based on the principle of residential origin, are the second major type of local network. People who have neither family ties nor do they come from the same village or neighborhood, are deemed "foreigners." Thus the historical demography of a neighborhood or village is very important as a basis for understanding systems of resource allocation. 58. The mosque, Mullah and elders are well respected, informal leaders in the community. The Mullah and the group of elders can play an active role in programming through information dissemination to the population; mobilizing resources for programs; monitoring quality and timely execution and conflict resolution. 59. Female counterparts to the Mullah--Bibikhallifah--are found both in towns and villages. Their main role is the religious education of women and performing religious ceremonies with women. More information is needed on other roles they play in communities of women.
 - 99 - 60. The Mahallah representative or Hudjain in villages is an informal leader elected by the community. The representative acts as a liaison to the formal local government structures. This type of local leader can be found in those areas not affected by the war. In GAO, it was found that the Hudjain works through a council, including one woman. 61. Representatives of formal institutions should not be expected to represent the communities since they are appointed from above and often are new arrivals from a different region and/or sector. These include: the town, district and regional representatives and farm officials. Other formal institutions such as the Women's Councils, the Youth League, etc., were found to be operating, if at all, then at a smaller scale than in the past. Since the demise of the Soviet Union, some of these had reformed as different entities but retained old links, such as the Youth League (formerly the Komsomol--i.e. Communist Youth League) which retains funding links to the Communist Party. 62. The SA found considerable local support for a participatory style of development. Communities would like to be involved program design. Elders are eager to play an active role in program monitoring, mobilization of resources. Local monitors should be independent from government, particularly in matters of resource allocation Information dissemination should be improved by using traditional leaders (Mullah, elders) and publicity at communal centers. Some of these have already been planned for or are partially constructed, others are programs which would allow the community to adjust better to the current situation. 65. The kinds of projects for which community proposals are likely to be developed are: Social infrastructure Waste water canal cleaning Irrigation repair Pump replacement Small water and sanitation stations Public baths and latrines Small hydroelectric plants Reconstruction of schools and health points, especially in war-affected or distant villages Kindergarten repairs or construction Reclaiming land: new irrigation canals, clearing rocks Constructing community storage for fruits and vegetables

Programs should be aware of traditional gender roles which often define activities in which women are willing to take part.
