The Agricultural Reforn and Social Protection Credit supports Government's efforts to improve social programs in three specific areas by: (a) protecting social sector bud get allocations; (b) improving the targeting of safety net expenditures; and (c) restructuring pension and social insurance programs. PROTECTING HEALTH AND EDUCATION EXPENDITURES 2. Since 1992, the education and health sectors have been severely impaired by the collapse in Government revenues and expenditures. The combined share of GDP that was allocated to these two sectors was 17 percent in 1992 and about seven percent of a much smaller GDP in 1995. As a consequence, supplies are scarce, wage payments have been irregular, and highly qualified staff continue to leave both sectors. School attendance is falling and indicators show a worsening of the nation's health, especially in the rural areas. There is an urgent need for emergency measures in these two sectors, including immediate efforts to improve the supply of textbooks and basic drugs. In the short-term, the priority is to ensure that these sectors receive a reasonable share of the severely constrained budget. Consequently, Government allocated a fifth of the 1996 budget to these two sectors -- 5.5 percent to health and 14.5 percent to education. TARGETING SOCIAL PAYMENTS: ALLOWANCES AND SUBSIDIES 3. Historically, household allowances and public enterprise subsidies were unsustainably large (18 percent of GDP in 1994) and inefficiently delivered. Subsidies to public enterprises, which represented about 13 percent of GDP in 1994, were a major part of the overall social protection system in Tajikistan because they allowed consumer prices to be kept below the cost of production. The bulk of these subsidies were for bread production (paras. 41 and 42), irrigation (para. 30), and transportation. To protect the poor from liberalization of transport prices, the Government will explore options for the use of transport vouchers for selected groups.The most important element of the social safety net in Tajikistan is the bread compensation allowance. Tajik households consume a relatively high level of bread products. Prior to May 1995, the Government provided a universal bread allowance of 1,800 Russian rubles for each citizen (representing 4.5 percent of GDP in 1994). Additionally, bread production was heavily subsidized (8.4 percent of GDP in 1994). As of July 1995, these subsidies amounted to 50 percent of the price of a loaf of bread and constituted an expensive universal subsidy that did little to target the poor. In August 1995, both the bread compensation allowance and the production subsidy were replaced by the reintroduction of a targeted bread allowance and a child allowance. In December 1995, the bread compensation allowance was doubled to compensate partially for liberalized bread prices. On March 1,
 - 103 - 1996, the Government fully liberalized the prices of bread and flour and increased the bread compensation allowance by an additional 70 percent. (Between August 1995 and June 1996 bread prices rose approximately eightfold reflecting the removal of public subsidies and higher local currency prices for imported wheat.) At the same time, the bread compensation and child allowances were combined into single social welfare payment. This social welfare payment, which amounts to TR500 per month, was targeted to children under 16 years old (for households with per capita income less than twice the minimum wage), non-working pensioners whose pensions are less than double the minimum wage, registered unemployed workers, and the disabled. Because of the dramatic changes in the economy in recent years, the present targeting system (which is based on 1993 household survey data) needs to be revised. The Government has decided to undertake a household survey in order to provide a better basis for targeting. In the 1996 budget, Government allocated TR7.8 billion for social welfare compensation. This allocation assumes 1.4 million of beneficiaries (out of a population of 5.8 million). Should the number of applicants for assistance during 1996 prove to be higher than expected, the Government will, in consultation with IDA, adopt corrective measures to keep the total amount of allowances within the budget allocation. TARGETING SOCIAL PAYMENTS: PENSION, SOCIAL INSURANCE AND EMPLOYMENT BENEFITS 4. In 1991, Government set up three extra-budgetary funds to replace the large social transfers from Moscow. Each of the three funds was given a share of the 39 percent tax on enterprise wage bills. Of the three funds, the largest is the Pension Fund, which receives just over 32 percentage points of the tax. The Social Insurance Fund and the Employment Fund account for six and one percentage points of the payroll tax, respectively. Since the end of 1993, inflation and the downward spiral of output has meant that enterprises have been unable or unwilling to pay the wage bill tax with the result that each of the funds has suffered serious revenue shortfalls. In turn, there have been many months when the funds have not been able to make payments to their beneficiaries. The current economic and financial situation provides little ground for optimism that regular full payments will be resumed in the near term. 5. The Pension Fund is responsible for the payment of retirement benefits (about three-quarters of the Fund's obligations) as well as payments for invalids and some other social benefits. Presently, there are numerous structural problems with the Pension Fund that have contributed to the current crisis. These include: (a) the fund's promise to pay pensions on the basis of workers' previous income, as if those workers were paying into an investment account, whereas current pension payments are based on current payments by enterprises; (b) isolation from the central government budgetary process; and (c) a rate of taxation on the wage bill is too high. Consequently, the system needs to be reformed to create an effective and sustainable social safety net -- albeit one with lower levels of benefits than during the Soviet era. Therefore, in June 1996, as a temporary measure, Government limited: (a) the value of pensions in order to achieve greater regularity in payments; and (b) the monthly payment to the amount of actual revenue collections. Further, Government has announced that all pensioners will be paid at the minimum rate and that the monthly surplus in the Pension Fund, if any, will be distributed to the eligible pensioners proportionately to their entitlements. Any arrears that are accumulated will be canceled at the end of each quarter. Additionally, Government has announced that pensions will no longer be paid to working pensioners.In order to improve the administration of social insurance, in February 1996, Government consolidated the collection of all payroll taxes under the responsibility of a single agency and centralized the collection and allocation of Pension Fund revenues to mitigate regional disparities. In
 -104- addition, the Government removed the responsibility for paying child allowances from the Pension Fund and integrated it with the social welfare payment. 6. The Social Insurance Fund is an extra-budgetary fund managed by the Governing Council of Trade Unions that pays sick leave and maternity benefits and also provides various worker amenities. As with the Pension Fund, the Social Insurance Fund has been unable to meet its commitments in recent years. Entitlement are generous by international standards and give rise, when in operation, to excessive use of limited health care services. Sick leave benefits provide up to 100 percent of a worker's salary for up to four months and birth grants are provided for up to three children. Recognizing the need to reduce these benefits, Government issued a decree that reduces maximum sick leave entitlement to one month per year and submitted the supporting legislation to the Majlisi Oli. Additionally, Government plans to transfer responsibility for sickness and maternity leave benefits to the enterprise responsible for employing the individual. 7. The Employment Fund was set up to finance the Employment Centers -- the main institutions through which certain benefits for labor are delivered, e.g., job placement, payment of unemployment benefits, public works for the unemployed, training and retraining, protection of disabled and disadvantaged workers, and registration and repatriation of refugees from the civil war. There are two immediate problems with Employment Centers that need to be addressed. First, as presently constituted, the unemployment funds are regional with the result if enterprises in a particular region do not pay the wage bill tax, unemployment benefits are not paid. A more centralized fund would allow inter-regional transfers to more distressed areas. Second, with the current unemployment benefits set equal to the minimum wage and an employment tax of one percent, the Employment Fund would run a deficit if those claiming benefits are more than four percent of the labor force. Therefore, Government has discontinued financing wage subsidies for maintaining jobs in financially distressed enterprises. SUPPLEMENTARY JOB-CREATION 8. The combination of only very slow economic recovery (and therefore slow employment growth) and a rapidly growing labor force (by at least 100,000 annually) mean the problem of unemployment will not be solved by growth in the near term. Even if economic growth were to be as much as five percent per year, in contrast to the projection of continuing decline for the next two to three years, the number of new jobs would still be only about 60,000 per year -- well short of what is necessary to absorb new entrants to the labor force.Recognizing the magnitude of the unemployment problem, Government has allocated TR150 million for the public works program managed by the Employment Service. Such an approach is especially attractive given the considerable amount of rehabilitation and reconstruction work (e.g., roads, bridges, schools and clinics) that needs to be completed. POVERTY ASSESSMENT 9. The Government needs assistance to prepare a comprehensive poverty reduction strategy. This would include preparing a profile of the poor and of vulnerable groups as well as mechanisms for monitoring changes in poverty. Because of acute data limitations, technical support will be needed to prepare this profile and the poverty reduction strategy. Under the Credit, agreement was reached with the Government on the terms of reference for a poverty assessment.

Cumming BACKGROUND 1. This review focuses primarily on NGOs which have an interest and programming capacity that has an economic as well as a social character and impact.(See table 1 for a summary of all International NGO programs in Tajikistan) OVERVIEW OF NGO SECTOR 2. This report deals more with foreign than with national or local NGOs. All available evidence suggests that local NGOs, to the extent that they exist, tend to be rather new, small and lacking in experience. Therefore, they would not be in a position to implement projects funded under the PPAP. 3. The pre-eminent exception to this rule would be the Pamir Relief and Development Program (PRDP) which was established by the Aga Khan Foundation. Though young, it operates with a level of resources not enjoyed by any other Tajikistan NGO. Another exception might be the national Red Crescent Society which is described as the largest domestic NGO in Tajikistan, in terms of its membership, with chapters throughout the country. 4. This fact points up a dilemma for the Bank. On the one hand, circumstances suggest the need for supporting activities likely to have relatively quick results. On the other, it would be desirable to build national and local NGO capacity for the longer run. This dilemma might best be resolved by giving priority support to those international NGOs which demonstrate the most serious evidence of involvement in building partnership with and in strengthening local and national NGO bodies. A. Networks Between/Among NGOs: In-country Networks 5. In the wake of the 1992-93 civil war, NGOs and donors working in Tajikistan began to meet regularly and formed a committee of international organizations. It currently meets every Monday morning. This initiative was previously convened by the UNHCR but is now being
 - 125- chaired by UNDP. The purpose of this grouping is to share information and, wherever possible, to co-ordinate action. Apart from the regular weekly donors meeting, the foreign NGOs meet once a month to discuss issues of concern to them. 6. There is no indigenous NGO coordinating organization in Tajikistan, though there is an NGO Resource Center which Counterpart Consortium (CC) has assisted. This is housed in the same building as Counterpart and shares facilities with that organization. 7. Counterpart and Save the Children (US) jointly support the NGO Capacity Building Project which is a training scheme for NGO staff, both those associated with local NGOs and the locally engaged Tajik staff of foreign NGOs. B. Networks in the Region or Beyond 8. The Project for Economic Reform and Development in Central Asia (PERDCA), though not itself an NGO, maintains an NGO support function in Central Asia, assisting NGOs to develop regional contacts. One of its services is Silknet, an electronic network connecting organizations in Tajikistan and neighboring republics. With assistance from the Eurasia Foundation and the Soros Foundation, it will continue to install sub-nodes throughout the region. 9. Counterpart Consortium (CC), with USAID assistance, maintains the Nongovernmental Organization Support Initiative for Central Asia. (It now has a Tajikistan office and, as noted above, is actively involved in training.) CC offers training for indigenous NGOs (management and sustainability), promotes and facilitates information exchange and partnerships and offers a seed grants program, including "partnership grants" for strengthening capacity to serve members and "corporate challenge grants" which encourage corporations to contribute matching monies. To the end of 1995, the Consortium reports that more than 300 Central Asian NGOs have received training, that a region-wide data base on local NGOs has been formed and is being continuously updated and that forty nine (49) grants totalling over $350,000 have been awarded throughout the region. C. Current/Planned NGO Projects: Refugee Assistance 10. Due to the conditions resulting from the civil war (1992-93), the UNHCR has played a leading role in humanitarian aid to Tajikistan to assist returning refugees and other displaced persons. 11. Some examples of NGO assistance to refugees include: * a study of the needs of refugees, with particular reference to water and sanitation which the IRC conducted in August-September, 1993. * the Aga Khan Foundation/PRDP humanitarian relief effort. One evaluation characterized the AKF feeding program as having "literally rescued the population of Gorno-Badakshan from the threat of famine" and, therefore, as one of the outstanding examples of NGO response.
 - 126 - * the SCF (US) assisted some 62,000 refugees and internally displaced persons in the wake of the civil war to rebuild and rehabilitate housing whilst feeding some 27,000 brigade workers through food for work projects. D. Micro-enterprise/Credit and Small Enterprise Development 12. The Tajikistan Government has defined micro-enterprises as those having up to nine (9) employees and small enterprises as having between ten (10) and one hundred and ninety-nine (199) employees. 13. Some examples are as follows: * SCF (U.S.) has been supporting a group guaranteed lending program (GGLP) at the village level in Khatlon Region (patterned after the ASA Program and Grameen Bank in Bangladesh) and has engaged in training for small enterprise development for women and their families as well as small business entrepreneurs. The early experience of this program has been quite positive; for instance, there has been a zero default rate on loans. i SCF (U.K.) has sponsored small enterprise development through a monetization scheme and small scale income generation projects. These have been specifically directed towards female headed households. - The Soros Foundation has provided financial assistance to both SCF (U.S.) and SCF (U.K.) for their micro-enterprise and credit schemes. For a period of about five months in early 1995, Mercy Corps International (MCI) sponsored monetization projects using food donated by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Through the mechanism of third-party agreements, all credits extended under such projects are repaid to local non- profit organizations and not to MCI. * Relief International (RI) has made a contribution through quick impact projects (QIPs) focusing on women heads of families. Ninety percent (90%) of business plan proposals (goat, sheep and poultry breeding, bread making, sewing, knitting, soap making and so on) had been accepted as of that time. * Shelter Now International (SNI) has supported capacity in small enterprise development through on-the-job training and the provision of building products. * Various NGOs have reported on projects which produce goods and materials. IRC, for instance, has been supporting the rehabilitation of small soap and shoe production industries.

The SCF (US) and CC trainers work as a team. 20. The Independent evaluation of the UNHCR SED projects concludes that "IRC's particular strength is capacity building". (Peduzzi, p. 18) In that this is an area of the most critical importance, IRC's response to this recommendation bears further examination. I. Health 23. Some NGOs have specialized in health programs. Though this is not a priority for the proposed Bank initiative, it is worthy of note that some NGOs have chosen to focus on health: * RI has made a substantial contribution in this area. A recent evaluation found, however, that its future may be compromised because the focus of its work has been with the government health service which is in a severe state of crisis due to economic and political conditions.
 - 130 - * SCF (US) has likewise been involved in health programming but has emphasized the development, strengthening and training of village health committees. It should be noted as well that some of the emerging Tajikistan NGOs are showing an interest in health. This is most notably true of women's and environmental organizations which are, respectively, concerned with women's and environmental health issues. J. Civil Society 26. Though most of the international NGO activity in the immediate wake of the civil war was concerned with emergency relief followed by reconstruction, there are NGOs which have demonstrated an interest in the question of what can be done to promote the growth of civil society. * The Counterpart Consortium, together with the American Legal Consortium, co-sponsored a regional conference on NGOs and the Law (October 29 to November 4, 1995). It makes seed grants to enable other initiatives to start. Then it moves on to other projects.

Even the UNHCR, though clearly not an NGO, received an initial contribution from the Foundation towards its work in the post civil war period. K. Analysis of NGO Operating Environment in Tajikistan: Political 28. From the top levels of Government, there is official receptivity to NGOs bringing relief and development assistance to Tajikistan - notwithstanding varying degrees of enthusiasm from ministry to ministry. The Government has responded positively to the idea that the a substantial portion of the proposed PPAP to be established through the World Bank loan would be devoted to NGO projects that have the potential for "scaling-up". 29. However, there has apparently been, it should be added, a recent demonstration of alleged government interference in the election of a the President of a national NGO, the Tajikistan Red Crescent Society. (The Red Crescent Society is the largest national NGO with branches throughout the country. One of its essential principles of operation is independence from the state.) Because of this alleged interference, the association called an extraordinary general meeting of the members. In order to ensure the freedom and independence of the meeting, invited official observers of both the ICRC and IFRC were present. The fact that interference evidently took place in the initial election and that international observers were brought in must be regarded as a disturbing sign, notwithstanding that a reversal was secured in this particular instance. An indigenous and autonomous Tajikistan NGO without this kind of international backing might well have had a more difficult experience. L. Legal 30. Because the legal situation of NGOs in Tajikistan has been reasonably well documented, the following will simply touch upon some salient features of the law and the regulatory environment. 31. The principal laws which apply to NGOs are the Constitution of the Republic of Tajikistan, which recognizes the concept of pluralism and the right of citizens to associate, and the Law of Public Associations (1991), which defines a public association as "a voluntary unit created by the free will of citizens who have united together on the basis of common interests". The definition encompasses a wide range of possibilities from trade unions to political parties, mass movements, associations of women, veterans and invalids as well as scientific, cultural and sporting organizations and so on. 32. The breadth of the field of possibilities is both a virtue and a possible problem. Some observers feel that the law lacks precision and a sense of the differences between one kind of organization and another. They note, in particular, the substantial distinctions to be made between a political party or a trade union and a voluntary association. On the other hand, they would not want to see the law become too restrictive. It is important to note that the Law on Public Associations is currently under review and amendments are likely to be presented within a few months time. 33. NGOs, both foreign and local, must register with the Ministry of Justice under the heading of "public associations". There are now over two hundred (200) "NGOs" thus registered, though only a small portion these are concerned with relief and/or development, and the majority of those are oriented to social welfare. There does, however, appear to be a significant number of environmental NGOs, perhaps reflecting a serious degree of concern about the state of the natural environment.
 - 132 - 34. The information which an NGO wishing to register with the Ministry of Justice must supply is as follows: * its name, purposes and goals; * its structure and the territory within which it will carry out its activities; * the rules for granting and terminating membership; * the rights and obligations of members; * the rules for forming governing bodies and structural subdivisions and the terms of office; * its sources of funds and other property; * the procedures for amending its charter; * the procedures for terminating activity and disposing of remaining property 35. The registration fees for an international public association amounts to $260 (US); organizations operating throughout the Republic must pay the equivalent of $80, and those operating in a rayon or local area, $55. Public associations representing invalids and children are exempt, and associations of women, veterans and youth pay fifty percent (50%) of the fees applicable. For most foreign NGOs, the fee is not a problem. Given the amount of cash available to most local citizens and organizations, however, the fees represent a hardship. Effectively, therefore, a great many local public associations will require foreign support even to pay their registration fees. 36. In the event of denial of registration, the right of appeal to the Supreme Court exists. 37. As regards taxes, the Public Associations Law specifies that Public Associations must pay taxes on "entrepreneurial activities". Under a decree of the Supreme Council of the Republic, there are certain exceptions to this rule, including enterprises and institutions related to associations of invalids, museums, libraries, theaters and so on. Rates of income taxes may be reduced where profits are devoted to charitable purposes. 38. In the event of an international treaty whose provisions are different from local legislation, the former will prevail. 39. It should be added that organizations operating in a particular region or locality must register with the department of justice of the particular regional council of people's deputies. 40. The formal legal requirements for establishing an foreign-based or international NGO in Tajikistan are minimal. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Department of International Organizations and International Law is the body which registers foreign NGOs. (There is no requirement that local NGOs register with the Foreign Ministry.) The organization must submit the following under cover letter: (i) its by-laws or charter;
 - 133 - (ii) a statement of its goals, objectives and activities in Tajikistan and; (iii) a written mandate from headquarters for the organization's senior official posted to the country. 41. Approval by the Foreign Ministry can be granted very quickly. The foreign NGO then has access to free consular services and many privileges available to the diplomatic corp. Some NGO representatives have observed that the Justice Ministry tends to be the controlling face of government, whereas the Foreign Ministry adopts a more facilitating stance with regard to the registration of foreign NGOs. 42. Finally, as regards micro and small enterprise development, there appears to be no legal problem in organizing and registering businesses. It is worthy of mention here since some of the foreign NGOs are sponsoring and encouraging micro and small enterprise activities. M. Regulatory 43. It is in the administration of the law where some NGOs observe or experience difficulties. For instance, as noted above, some have found attitudes held by some Justice officials to be "dirigiste". On the other hand, a senior official of the same Ministry confirmed to this author that the policy of the Government is to encourage a vibrant NGO sector which can help to address the severe socio-economic problems which the country is facing. 44. The experience of local NGOs in securing the registration of their charters varies considerably. Some speak of the procedures as being complicated and cumbersome, of having had to wait two years or more and of having had to submit answers to questions not asked at the outset. There is a feeling that "city NGOs" with access to money and government offices have an easier time than rural ones, and especially those which represent the very poor. One NGO representative claimed that officials sometimes seek bribes. Other organizations, however, appear to have enjoyed a relatively easy process. It may be that some types of associations, those which represent disabled people for instance, find more ready acceptance because their categories are specifically recognized in law. 45. Taxation matters are the source of a good deal of concern for NGOs, both foreign based and local. Notwithstanding that the Public Associations Law appears to restrict taxation to "entrepreneurial activities" that might be carried on public associations - and hence profits earned - there does appear to be considerable confusion regarding how the law is to be interpreted. Several NGO representatives interviewed in the course of the May, 1996 Mission spoke of their fear that their revenues, regardless of source or purpose, will be taxed. This has led some to operate on a cash system rather than through a bank. Whilst most registered NGOs appear not to be paying taxes, this uncertainly is obviously not very satisfactory, and clarification is needed. The problem appears to be that a distinction between profits earned from business activity on the one hand and revenues generated from charitable giving and official donors on the other may not be well understood. There would also appear to be an element of confusion about national pension plan contributions. This whole area of taxation and related matters is of concern and will need to be followed carefully.

Given the political/economic situation of Tajikistan, it is difficult to imagine there being much potential, for some time to come, to move away from substantial reliance on foreign funding. Some forms of program activity, however, do involve less external funding than others. Revolving loan funds, for instance, maximize local effort and recycle money within the economy. R. Project Sustainability 55. Inflation has been mentioned as a major factor. Political and social stability are key elements of sustainability. 56. The 1995 Feasibility Study on Enterprise Development makes the point that sustainability, at least in the agricultural area, may be enhanced by giving in-kind contributions (seeds, fertilizers, fuel and the like) with repayment pegged to agricultural output calculated in hard currency. 57. Another of the factors contributing to project sustainability is the gestation and implementation periods required. This is an issue that the Bank will need to consider in relation to any expectation of quick return. An evaluation of the UNHCR's Tajikistan small enterprise development projects is instructive when it calls attention to the contradiction between quick impact and long term development. 58. Conflict resolution and peace building are matters of urgent need. Though virtually all NGOs
 - 136- claim to be non-discriminatory as far as employment and other project benefits are concerned, few have explicit and practiced strategies for addressing social conflict. The USAID PVO evaluation notes, however, that the SCF (US) has "been among the leading practitioners of the art". The May, 1996 Bank Mission found a general awareness of the problems of social conflict among NGOs with which it met, though it did not detect much NGO programming activity in the area. This having been said, there is a UNDP sponsored pilot project operated by UN volunteers. (An evaluation of the project was underway at the time of the Mission's visit.) S. Staff capacity 59. There is an abundance of well educated and talented local people available in Tajikistan. Though most of these are not experienced in the design and management of development projects and programs, many have found work with NGOs and have proved themselves very adaptable. 60. Because of the conditions of living and working in Tajikistan, foreign NGO staff have tended to stay for rather short periods of time, thus contributing to a turnover problem. This issue has been complicated by the change in role experienced as a result of coming to the country as relief agencies and more recently having tried to make a transition to development. The staff who are suitable for a relief operation are often not those most appropriate for a development program. T. Transition from Relief to Development 61. The shift from relief to development is frequently not an easy one for NGOs whose orientation and experience is in relief programming. Even though these agencies may be extremely professional and competent in what they do, and though they are able to employ some needed expertise for development projects, they do not necessarily have the broader institutional awareness and support capacity which more seasoned development NGOs possess and use to good effect. This experiential gap showed itself in such areas as public participation in the planning, design and management of projects. Some organizations lack an intuitive and methodological grasp of how to proceed, simply because it is not part of their experience. U. Geographical Limitations 62. The other impediment is very much related to the foregoing point. Most of the present NGO projects are to be found in areas where the 1992-93 civil conflict occurred. These, in other words, are the parts of the country where their experience has been acquired. As a result, NGO relief, reconstruction and development projects are unevenly distributed throughout Tajikistan. "Scaling-up" through replication of activities in other areas, and, more especially, starting entirely new activities in new areas, are risky options and are steps which most NGOs would take very cautiously. The presence of NGOs in certain regions but not in others is an additional problem when it comes to distributing activities and benefits in an equitable fashion throughout the country. Moreover, this is a problem which is unlikely to be entirely solved in the short run. V. Factors Contributing to/Constraining Scaling-up 63. Money is an obvious factor. Stable or unstable economic conditions constitute another set of factors. If prices of inputs and/or products vary wildly or unpredictably, they negatively affect investment, production and sales and hinder any consideration of "scaling-up".
 - 137 - 64. The management capacity of NGOs themselves. On the surface, there is no reason to doubt that the organizations proposing "scaled-up" activities can manage what they claim to be able to do. However, the ability of each organization to manage and be accountable for projects undertaken is something that can be addressed closer to the time of actual decisions. 65. In addition to management capacity are the questions of orientation and expertise. These too are aspects that need careful assessment when considering potential projects to support. One general observation is that most of the foreign NGOs operating in Tajikistan came in an emergency relief role during or after the 1992-93 civil conflict. Some of these are organizations which have evolved over many years both a developmental and an emergency response capacity and practice. Historically, however, others have been known almost exclusively as relief organizations. In the Tajikistan context, some have advanced farther than others in redirecting their programs to development. W. Examples of "Scaling-up" Activities 66. A reading of various reports on NGO activities in Tajikistan would suggest a number of possibilities. Micro-enterprise development assisted through credit schemes is one such. The SCF (US) Group Guaranteed Lending Program, for instance, has proved so successful in Khatlon Region that the agency is considering replicating it in other parts of the country. The AKF Fund for Economic Development is presently considering the establishment of a small credit scheme to begin in Gorno- Badakshan and, depending on experience, expand to other parts of Tajikistan. Representatives of the foreign NGO community in Tajikistan have, by and large, had no experience working with the World Bank; the Government of Tajikistan has had little more; and NGOs and the GOT have, to date, had what might be termed a distant relationship. There will, therefore, have to be effective means of communication and co-ordination between and among the parties and some deliberate mutual confidence-building. 68. Because the proposed loan will be provided from the Bank to the GOT, both parties will have to agree on the basic terms of the agreement and the purposes for which the money will be spent. Government, for its part, will have to be satisfied that the projects reflect the best possible national priorities, and the Bank will need to ensure consistency with its own purposes as well as probity and accountability. 69. Notwithstanding the tripartite nature of the relationship which will have to be worked out, there is much to be said for an "arm's length" project management facility. Indeed, the credibility of the mechanism, at least in the eyes of participating NGOs and perhaps others in addition, may well depend on this arrangement. The facility will need to be and be seen to be honest, efficient and competent. Though it will have to adhere to the policies laid down and agreed upon and be accountable for its actions, it will need to be free from day-to-day interference. 70. The possible contradiction between this sort of "arm's length" facility and the desirability of developing capacity within Government is one that is sufficiently obvious as to require comnment. Given all the problems of setting up a mechanism within the GOT which would satisfy the tests suggested by the foregoing point, and which could be able to operate quickly, one is led to the conclusion that this

 - 142 - ANNEX L REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN PILOT POVERTY ALLEVIATION PROJECT KEY INDICATORS FOR MONITORING AND INTEGRATED EVALUATION INTRODUCTION 1. An independent evaluation of the Project would assess overall performance against its objectives of (a) impact on household incomes and (b) capacity building. It would provide a comprehensive and independent analysis of the results of the projects and the efficiency of the use of available resources, and derive lessons to be learned. The evaluation is designed so as to ensure both that its findings are independent and reliable, and also that it is conducted in a participatory way (involving both implementors and beneficiaries) that will maximize learning. 2. Such an evaluation has particular importance for a pilot project with the express aim of charting a path for expanded future investments in poverty alleviation, in a country where the Bank has as yet little implementation experience. An evaluation, conducted at mid term and completion, would enable three key things: (i) ensure at mid-term that lessons learnt in the first Project component are consolidated and incorporated in the second; and (ii) provide a "lessons learned" context for the preparation of a follow-up project based on the second component, and (iii) provide important pointers for future more specialized sector work including infrastructure, health, education and micro-credit. 3. The overall evaluation would verify and integrate the results of separate evaluations of the individual components and sub-components of the Project (although its scope would not necessarily be restricted by them), and on the results of monitoring incorporated in each component. In order to allow this to happen, key indicators need to be established that can be measured in a compatible fashion across both components of the Project at three points in time: baseline, mid-term and end-of-project. For this reason, the evaluation is termed "integrated". The remainder of this annex covers the three related topics of key objective indicators, the conduct of the integrated evaluation, and monitoring indicators. OBJECTIVE INDICATORS 4. Key objective indicators would be measured and maintained by the Project in order to track, in a consistent and comparable fashion, the essentials of performance against objectives. The key objective indicators are summarized below in Table 1, and discussed in the following paragraphs. The first Project objective of impact on the incomes of the poor would be measured across all sub-components by five key indicators, of which two would indicate the extent to which this objective has been met in a cost effective and participatory fashion. These indicators, and the specific measures and instruments to compile them, would be refined in a pilot baseline exercise . A. Poverty Impact Indicators 5. It is difficult in situations such as Tajikistan to measure household incomes reliably, owing to the importance of non-monetary items. The social assessment pointed to three key proxy indicators that were highly sensitive to household poverty levels and appear suitable for generalization across all sub-components (Annex F). Food security and nutrition is the single best measure of household economic status and purchasing power, food being the largest budget item for poor households. Food insecurity needs to be measured in its dimensions of incidence, depth and seasonality. The nutritional status of children can be measured by standard rapid survey techniques, such as MUAC (mid upper-arm circumference) used extensively by UNICEF. (Two sub-components whose design permits the direct measurement of household incomes on a small scale are identified in the next section). 6. Clothing, especially shoes for children, is the second priority of poor households, particularly in areas subject to winter cold. 7. Shelter and fuel is the third key household incomes proxy indicator. The availability of domestic fuel for cooking, and for heating during the winter months, is a critical concern of poor families. Local scales should be constructed for standards of overcrowding in sleeping accommodation, together with a simple score for shelter quality (leaky roof, no windows, no flooring etc.). An indicator of household durables (beds, mattresses etc.) might be added. 8. A common or compatible calculation of cost-effectiveness would show cost per beneficiary for certain types of specified or measured benefits. 9. An indicator of community participation would show the scale and intensity of local involvement in the planning, implementation, financing and monitoring of programs. Community participation is seen primarily as an approach rather than an objective. However, a participatory approach was an important criterion for the selection of programs for scaling up in the first Project component and is expected to be a prominent feature of TASIF microprojects in the second component. Moreover, the close relationship between local powerlessness and poverty revealed by the social assessment points to community participation in poverty alleviation activities, together with institutional capacity-building (discussed below), as being an important indicator of social capital formation.
 - 145 - B. Specific program indicators 10. The performance of each program would be evaluated according to three key indicators specific to the objectives of that program. While each program would have its range of additional indicators for monitoring and individual internal evaluations, the three specific indicators are selected primarily to measure the aspects of coverage, delivery of the specific benefit, and longer term sustainability. 11. The shelter program has as its main objective to assist 2,000 returned families with shelter in five districts. Beneficiary selection would ensure the inclusion of the neediest and most vulnerable groups, including female headed households and ethnic minorities. Locally- manufactured tiles would be used in place of asbestos sheeting. The three specific indicators therefore measure (i) the quantity of shelter improved as a result of the project and the number of households benefiting, in proportion to the overall identified need (ii) the inclusion of poor and vulnerable categories of households as beneficiaries; and (iii) the adoption of tile technology. 12. The micro-credit program aims to extend a group savings and credit guarantee scheme to 3,750 poor women in 250 groups, and to build institutional capacity. The three specific indicators would measure (i) the active loan portfolio, comprising the number of beneficiaries, the loan volume and the repayment rates, indicating the extent to which poor women are able to access the benefit; (ii) the change in household incomes as a result of the project, and (iii) the creation of productive micro-enterprises as a result. The measurement of household incomes, impractical for application across the Project, is feasible within the restricted context of this program by virtue of its regular monitoring, and will allow testing of simple and inexpensive methods of investigating household budgets. The creation of productive micro-enterprises is an important indicator of the future sustainability and replicability, showing the productive use of household credit as investment, rather than for short-term consumption needs. The important component of institution-building is captured by a general indicator. 13. The Female-Headed Households program would provide support for household food production to 3,700 female-headed households to improve food security and incomes. The three specific indicators selected are (i) the number of participating households; (ii) household incomes, for the same reason as in the micro-credit program, and (iii) food productivity. The range of institutional and group formation benefits, including community day care centers, schools and access to local services would be captured either in the first specific indicator, or in the general indicators of community participation and institutional capacity. 14. The agricultural reform program aims to increase food crop production and productivity in six of seven districts in Gorno-Badakhshan, by bringing additional land into cultivation through small scale self-help irrigation channels. This would benefit 1,600 resource-poor farming households. The three specific indicators would measure the (i) the land development potential (length of channels constructed and potential command area realized); (ii) actual land development (number of hectares developed for cultivation, number of households benefiting; and (iii) actual increase in food production and productivity by family and unit area. The evaluation would take into account that the land development schedule extends for several years beyond the life of the Project, and that therefore the benefit stream for some may commence after Project completion.

The second Project objective of capacity building is to strengthen in country capacity to develop and implement poverty alleviation programs through (i) development of TASIF as a central organization to fund and provide technical support for microprojects; and (ii) through the first Project component, to build up local community, NGO and local government capacity to initiate and organize poverty alleviation programs at local level. 16. Three indicators would be used to measure and evaluate Project performance and the achievement of this objective: (i) the development of national and local institutional capacity to implement participatory poverty alleviation programs; (ii) the number of national and local government officials trained in project identification, proposal preparation and community participation, together with the number of proposals received by TASIF, and (iii) the number of TASIF staff trained in these skills. The first two of these indicators are common to both components of the program, while the third is specific to the second component. 17. The institutional capacity indicator is both qualitative and quantitative, and must be measured at several levels: A. Each of the programs in the first Projct component has a specific local institutional objective which is both a means and an end: participation through community-based organizations and associations of beneficiaries. The work groups of the shelter program, the micro-credit groups and umbrella NGO, the associations of female headed households and the managements of day care centers and schools, the local farmers' groups negotiating irrigation channels, all play an important part in empowering the poor and marginalized to organize to improve their conditions. They help rebuild civil society and ensure sustainability of process and impact in poverty alleviation. The indicator at this level would measure scale (size, geographical and social coverage), scope and institutional strength. The design of an instrument and a method to capture this aspect objectively, in the context of the diversity of organizations emerging will be a challenge for the baseline evaluation to resolve. B. At the second tier, the institutional capacity of local government officials, and local or national NGOs to target, appraise, implement and monitor poverty alleviation programs can be determined by simple institutional assessments on a common checklist. C. At the third tier of TASIF itself, the key measures of capacity would be results against its central objective, the ability to channel investments through community microprojects for poverty alleviation, and to ensure and account for the results. 18. The second key capacity building indicator is trained officials. This indicator would capture the number and geographical distribution of national and local government officials and NGO officials trained in project identification, proposal preparation and community participation. The indicator would measure training effort (person-days, cost) against intended results, such as
 - 147 - the number, quality and distribution of proposals received by TASIF, or changes in knowledge, attitudes and practice. Measured across the Project, this indicator would capture the extent to which the four NGO programs, and TASIF itself, have contributed lessons, demonstration, training for replication of their successes over a wider geographical and institutional canvas. Additionally, each training event should have a simple internal evaluation as standard quality control practice. 19. The third key capacity building indicator is training within TASIF itself, the only indicator in Table 1 is not measured "across the board". As with the previous indicator, this indicator should measure not only training effort but training results in terms of knowledge, attitudes and practice that contribute to the organization's mission and performance. 20. The above set of indicators would facilitate and provide a sound foundation for an integrated and overall evaluation and should therefore be emphasized in monitoring. The integrated evaluation, however, would not be limited or determined by these indicators. MONITORING INDICATORS 21. Each program has specified its own monitoring indicators, which have four main purposes: management of implementation, triggering disbursements, tracking impact, and providing a foundation for subsequent evaluation. The range of these indicators, and how they would be measured, is shown in Table 4 at the end of this Annex. D. Establishing a baseline (May 1997) 22. To assess the Project's overall impact requires a baseline study, that would allow the key objective indicators in Table 1 to be measured in a compatible fashion across the Project's several programs. The first of two main steps to accomplish this is to develop, through workshops and pilot field exercises, instruments and procedures to operationalize these indicators. By the time of Project approval [April-May 1997], measurement of the key indicators in Table 1 would have been pilot tested through a workshop and field exercises that would bring together the NGOs, the TASIF monitoring and evaluation officer and relevant local consultants or research organizations under expert technical assistance. The indicators would be not only expert derived, but would include indicators selected in consultation with local commnities and capable of being measured by them; 23. Having agreed and tested measurement of the indicators and constructed a suitable sample frame6', quantitative and qualitative baseline data would then be collected and analyzed by the four NGOs and by TASIF for the first batch of 10-15 micro-projects, to establish quantified measures. The inclusion of TASIF in the baseline exercises would improve learning from the first to the second Project components, and facilitate the setting up of a fuller beneficiary assessment for later TASIF micro-projects. 6/ A 10 per cent sample of direct beneficiaries, plus a control group of suitable size, seems appropriate.
 - 148 - MANAGEMENT OF INTEGRATED EVALUATION A. Objectives 24. The integrated evaluation would determine the extent to which the Project had achieved its objectives, and particularly evaluate the following aspects, without necessarily being limited by them: A. design (needs identification, selection of intervention strategy, targeting) B. social and geographical targeting C. impact D. sustainability (of process and of impact) E. community participation F. cost effectiveness, relating the identified benefits to resources invested G. replicability B. Design and method 25. The evaluation has been designed in order to ensure the following features: (i) the independence, multi-disciplinary professionalism, integrity and reliability of its conclusions; (ii) the effective participation of beneficiaries and implementors; and (iii) the generation of maximum learning and capacity building. Any tension between the first objective (independence and integrity) and the second (participation of implementors and beneficiaries) would be resolved by ensuring a collegial approach under an independent leader. 26. A three-week mid-term evaluation would be conducted about June-July 1998, linking and coordinating the findings of the separate evaluations of the four NGO programs comprising the first Project component. It would verify through field visits the validity of key monitoring indicators and the essential accuracy of the quarterly progress reports, and review the training materials under preparation. The progress of the TASIF MIS would be assessed against these findings, with particular emphasis on (i) assisting with the identification of simple and effective monitoring and evaluation instruments, and the inclusion of community-based indicators; and (ii) the design of the TASIF microprojects beneficiary assessment. The design and selection of microprojects would also be evaluated. In reviewing Project progress against key indicators, the mid-term evaluation should pay particular attention to an initial institutional capacity assessment of TASIF, in order to allow time for recommendations to be taken into consideration during the second year of the Project. 27. The focus of the mid-term evaluation would be on lessons learned and Project course correction. TASIF, local communities and NGOs would all have the opportunity of mutual learning and education. 28. A final four-week evaluation would be conducted in June-July 1999, combining the evaluations of the four NGO programs, a selection of the TASIF microprojects, the beneficiary assessment, and an institutional assessment of TASIF. The evaluation team would make site visits to a selection2' of TASIF microprojects to verify monitoring and reporting procedures 1 A 20 percent sample of projects is recommended. It would be important to ensure a representative range of examples of success or difficulty in implementation.
 - 149 - against observations. The central questions to be addressed, on the basis of an analysis of key indicators, are: (i) the justification of continuing or expanding investments in poverty alleviation through participatory micro-projects; (ii) the lessons learned that would maximize the cost- effective impact and sustainability of such investments; and (iii) the capacity of TASIF to manage such investments effectively. The final evaluation would also relate its findings to the expectations and judgments of the PAD, so as to derive lessons for future project preparation. C. Management and inplementation 29. The evaluation exercise, both mid-term and final, would be contracted competitively by TASIF, subject to no objection from the Bank, to a suitably experienced and qualified lead individual or organization who has not been involved in project design, preparation or implementation. The evaluation leader would, in consultation with TASIF and the implementing NGOs, assemble a multi-disciplinary team of eight well-qualified local and international experts, ensuring a sufficient range of expertise to cover the project content: poverty and its alleviation, construction, micro-credit, gender, agriculture, institutional capacity and MIS training, community participation. Of the team, three or four international members would be proposed, one by each of the international NGOs, and paid for from their program budget. At least four local counterparts would be selected by the team leader and paid for from TASIF's budget. Interested relevant donors might also be invited to participate. TASIF's Monitoring and Evaluation Officer would actively assist the team with research documentation and analysis. 30. The evaluation team would work as an interdisciplinary team, reviewing each of the programs, and the TASIF microprojects, with full access to all project sites, personnel and documentation, and the ability to conduct their own spot field research. The team leader would be responsible for using all of the inputs and reports from the team members, and would have full responsibility for the end-product. 31. In addition, the team would be expected to constitute local evaluation teams for brief participatory, on-site evaluations. These local teams should include community representatives, local government officials, other knowledgeable or local persons, and representatives of the implementing agency. 32. The team would have access to all relevant TASIF and NGO records. and would be expected to ensure physical visits to project sites in each region of the country. D. Outputs 33. The consultant would produce a report in Russian and in English for each of the three evaluation components that would be confidential to TASIF, the implementing NGOs and the Bank. TASIF and the implementing NGOs would ensure dissemination of relevant findings to participating communities. 34. These reports would be made available in final form one month after the evaluation.

 - 168 - ANNEX 0 REPUBLIC OF TAJIKISTAN PILOT POVERTY ALLEVIATION PROJECT PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION SCHEDULE 1. The Pilot Poverty Alleviation Project (PPAP) would increase the incomes of some of the poor in Tajikistan and improve their access to essential economic and social services. This would be done by (a) scaling up selected existing NGO programs that are having a positive impact on poverty alleviation, and (b) developing the Tajikistan Social Investment Fund (TASIF) as a demand driven, cost-effective and transparent funding mechanism that would respond to proposals from the local level to carry out small investments in social and economic infrastructure. It would also finance the implementation of 70 microprojects throughout Tajikistan. Implementation Arrangements 2. The executing agency for the PPAP would be the newly established TASIF. The TASIF would be created by Presidential Resolution with the necessary autonomy and authority to enable it to execute the project according to the Legal Credit Agreement. The TASIF would operate according to a detailed Operational Manual which would provide information on the organization and structure of the TASIF. A draft of the Operational Manual would be prepared by TASIF prior to Project Effectiveness based on those used in other social funds and input from the World Bank and technical assistance. The Operational Manual would detail the implementation arrangements for microprojects as well as the responsibilities of the TASIF in monitoring, supervision and reporting on the NGO programs supported by the PPAP. 3. The TASIF would enter into service contracts with each of the NGOs to be supported through the PPAP. Attachments to the service contracts would stipulate the procedures, benchmarks and monitoring indicators to be followed by the NGOs for implementation of the NGO programs. Currently the TASIF Executive Director and the leadership of the NGOs are finalizing the details of the proposals and reaching consensus on the delegation of responsibilities for financial management, monitoring and reporting. Procurement and Disbursement 4. Given the nature of the project, it is difficult to estimate of procurement and disbursement procedures and schedules. These would be discussed with the World Bank mission and the NGOs during the forthcoming appraisal mission. The procurement arrangements for the NGO programs would be specified in attachments to the service contracts. Procurement arrangements for the microprojects and purchasing of equipment, furniture and consulting contracts would be specified in the Operational Manual.
 - 169 - Financing 5. The total project costs are estimated at US$11 million, of which IDA would finance US$10 million. The Government of Tajikistan and communities would contribute to the costs as well. Project Accounting and Monitoring 6. By project effectiveness, the TASIF would have hired staff and acquired equipment and technology to enable it to monitor and account for the use of PPAP funds. External auditing would be conducted on an annual basis. A beneficiary impact assessment would be undertaken to understand the impact of the project on poor communities. Completion of the PIP 7. The TASIF will complete its Project Implementation Plan by appraisal of the project. The TASIF will specify critical factors that could affect the success of the project, the role of the World Bank during project implementation, and a detailed schedule of implementation activities.

doc.abstracts: The development objective of the Pilot Poverty Alleviation Project is to increase on a sustainable basis the incomes of the poor, and to improve their access to essential economic and social services. The Project objectives are to: (1) have a modest though quick impact on the incomes of some of the poor; and (2) develop capacity at the national and local level to implement participatory approaches to poverty alleviation. The Project's two components are: scaling-up of on-going nongovernmental organization poverty alleviation programs; and developing the Tajikistan Social Investment Fund (TASIF). The first component further consists of: (1) assisting returned families in the self-help reconstruction of their homes ; (2) expanding existing services and extending activities of the micro-credit program to other districts; (3) strengthening the capacity of social services to support female-headed households with access to and ownership of agricultural assets, and with grants for day-are centers and schools; (4) expanding the agricultural reform program; and increasing staple food crop production; and (5) continued sponsoring of these activities, if they or similar programs modeled after them are successful. The development of the Social Investment Fund has two sub-components. In the first, TASIF will be developed by providing equipment, vehicles, salaries, operating costs, training, technical assistance, and financing for monitoring and evaluation. The second sub-component implements pilot micro-projects in order to train staff and test and modify the targeting, promotion, appraisal, approval, supervision, monitoring and evaluating procedures written in the operational manual.
